author: Andrew â€œAndyâ€ Davis
text:
Great ramen restaurant with really good flavorful broth and probably the most special taste. The pesto ramen with cheese and bacon combined with pork belly is spectacular. They have mushroom and bean sprout appetizers that are great and the karaage chicken is good and crispy paired with mayo for a great chicken  dish to share. The restaurant is a chain with several dotted around, their restaurants in Tianmu and Xinyi are my favorites. You canâ€™t reserve seating so come and be prepared to queue. Great food and highly recommend giving it a try.

author: NurembergAfterMidnight
text:
This place was hard! to find. It's located in the caesar's hotel. Find the side of the building to enter a food court. Google sent me down the MRT instead :'D

They try to make you order with your phone and QR code but everything there is Chinese. It's usually busy, but be persistent and ask them, they can order manually for you too! The food itself was delicious, tasted a little bit like Italian and Japanes food had a baby. But it's not that cheap compared to other places I ate. Vegetarian options exist and there's more than one! Cheese was generally nice too.

author: Kee Seng Heng
text:
ä¸€çœŸäº­ãƒ©ãƒ¼ãƒ¡ãƒ³
Ramen speciality shop

Located nearby to Wuxing Street, which is extremely close to Taipei University Hospital, this humble shop offers an extremely great taste of ramen. If not mistaken, the owner is a Japanese from Kyushu, and one thing for sure is that you can feel the passion of the chef and owner once you entered the shop. Small and humble shop, offers enough spaces for everyone to have a wonderful ramen tasting experience.

The menu offers several types of ramen, and basically the top 3 categories are èµ¤ (Red, more towards spicy ramen), ç™½ (White, more to original broth), and é»‘ (Black, more towards black sauce). There are other types like Curry ramen, and cold ramen too. If you're craving for a beer to go with the ramen, they have it too! Haha.

Orderedã€Œç‰å­ç‡’ã€- Tamago. Delicious and perfect side dishes as starter and to go along with the ramen. Though it's a bit cold, as in, it's served cold instead of hot, but nevertheless still pretty delicious.

Orderedã€Œèµ¤ è¾£å‘³å‰ç‡’éºµ + ç³–å¿ƒè›‹ + å‰ç‡’ã€- Spicy Char Siew Pork Ramen + More Half Boiled Egg + More Char Siew Pork! Definitely one of the best Japanese ramen I've ever had in Taiwan. The broth is thick, but not greasy nor oily, making every sip of it is extremely pleasant to the tongue (one of the few ramens where I drank the entire soup! Haha). The noodle (I choose harder texture, my preferences) is having the perfect texture, and soaked well with the broth too. The half boiled egg, ah... my kryptonite, everytime I see a perfectly served half boiled egg, it's a major thumbs up from me. Tender outside with silky runny egg yolk, that's the perfection. The Char Siew Pork is grilled to perfect burn, and the meat is more towards lean meat with slight fats on top of it. All combined in this single bowl of wonderful taste.

(ç”± Google æä¾›ç¿»è­¯)

author: Lorraine
text:
A unique ramen, in my opinion. Definitely recommend you to try it. Normally, I am not a fan of seafood ramen, but they managed to create a thick shrimp - pork broth that i fell in love with. Their pork rice is a win as well, the crispy red shrimp on top is delicious. I was expecting a long wait time, but when i visit, there was no queue. I don't know if this is normal or if I was lucky.
The price is expectedly a bit high; considering the location as well. But I will definitely revisit!

text:
One of the best ramen in town where you can customize the ramen to your liking. Ramen was good and fulfilling. It is highly recommended.

If you are hungry in the middle of the night, Ichiran Ramen should be on the top of your list of where to go since it opens 24 hours. You might see people queuing up even 2-3am here.

author: Kevin L
text:
This is probably by far the worst ramen iâ€™ve had in my life. The noodles tasted very hard and the broth didnâ€™t have any taste at all. The charshu pork was also not really cooked which gave the ramen a very weird taste. I ordered the spicy pork ramen which was $270NTD and it didnâ€™t even have any spicy taste to it whatsoever.

Not only that, but what shook me was how slow the service was and how rude and disrespectful the boss was. There were kids that came with their parents and one of their kids sat at the chairs and the boss shouted â€œDONT SIT DOWN UNTIL YOUâ€™VE ORDEREDâ€, but the kid didnâ€™t hear it and the boss had a negative attitude which gave the whole restaurant a really bad vibe. Save your money go elsewhere.

â€¦. And before delving into the proverbial elephant in the room, let us first discuss the staple: the traditional Tonkotsu wheat noodle.
Thinly cut, soft and chewy, the starch is satisfactory albeit derivative. Despite the dishesâ€™ eccentricities, this mild disappointment is offset by a bottomless supply of noodles from the kitchen; an amends of sort for once the ensemble turns primarily to broth (or most likely to apologize for the $290NT price tag).
The protein of this exorbitant ramen is offered up by free-range fowl, char siu and flame charred. The birdâ€™s bounty is harvested same-day and soft-boiled, selected for itâ€™s deep pigmented yolk to complement the dazzling broth.
Speaking of broth, time now is to discuss the aforementioned elephant. Colored naturally from the â€˜clitoria ternateaâ€™, commonly known as the butterfly pea, this liberally salted trademark is what yields the queue of patrons circling the block (my wait time clocked in at 42 minutesâ€¦. in the rain). This vibrant plant is native only to Taiwan and remote islands of Indonesia, where itâ€™s woefully known not for the culinary industry, but rather in spiritual ceremonies such as Hinduismâ€™s Puja.
However, in contrary to past food criticsâ€™ reviews, this ramen is certainly no religious awakening.
Instead itâ€™s likenend to a nostalgic grade school science experiment, where one discovers that blue and yellow create green. In fact, this statement rings literal, as once the egg is invitably punctured by onesâ€™ chopsticks, itâ€™s orange yolk fuses with the cerulean broth. The conclusion of this kitschy endeavor leaves the bowl a baby diarrhea greenâ€” a much more burdensome presentation than the pictures and conversations commonly reveal.

author: Greg Hao
text:
The bowls of ramen at this shop are all well crafted and quite tasty. The scallops in my yuzu ramen was grilled without overcooking and had great texture. The chasu were sliced super thin which unfortunately I thought did not contribute much to this otherwise excellent bowl. Come, grab a number and walk around the neighborhood as you do not have to stand in line waiting to be seated.

author: Robert Smith
text:
Ramen Ultra was a spur of the moment decision and I was actually super impressed with the food. Iâ€™m not actually a big soupy noodle fan because I think itâ€™s too hot and messy, but I was so happy with their alternative called Tsukemen which is a smaller bowl of soup that you dip the noodles into. And to keep the protein content high I ordered a steamed chicken breast which was served on shredded cucumbers. I also had to get fries for the kids and they had traditional ramen and a beef bowl. I definitely think itâ€™s worth checking out and the price was about average for any sit down restaurant in this building.

author: Glen Matthew
text:
A humble ramen bar in walking distance from SYS Memorial Hall MRT Station. I was coming here around 10 minutes before they open and I already saw some queue.

You can order the ramen through vending machine next to the entrance. Sadly, they donâ€™t have any English menu as everything only available in Mandarin. However, the chef itself will help you as much as he can and it worked for me!

The taste of ramen was okay. I ordered the pork ramen with thick broth. Furthermore, the price itself was good compare to the similar ramen bar Iâ€™ve visited in Taipei.

author: Kee Seng Heng
text:
OkaeriãŠå¸°ã‚Šåƒç¢—æ‹‰éºµå§â €
Japanese Ramen Restaurantâ €
â €
For those that love thick and heavy flavor ramen - this is definitely highly recommended for you. For me, this is easily one of the top ten ramen that I love. Small and humble restaurant located near to Sun Yat Sen Memorial Hall MRT Station, and nearby to lots of other eateries, this shop serves traditional ramen in very traditional restaurant settings as well. More towards a darker and dimmed lightning inside the shop, and thereâ€™s a special spotlight-kinda lighting to every seat, every photo that you take on the ramen (which I would recommend you to focus more on eating, haha) will turn out to be a masterpiece. I definitely love this, and would definitely return to this ramen shop from time to time.â €
â €
Ordered é»‘è’œæ²¹è±šéª¨æ‹‰éºµï¼ˆæ¯æ—¥é™é‡ï¼‰- Black Garlic Oil Tonkatsu Ramen (Limited Daily) with extra æ»·å‰è…¿å‰ç‡’ (Braised Pork Char Siew) - Awesome to the heaven, I really mean it. First off, the broth is extremely thick in flavor - highly recommended for those that love thick flavor broth. The amount of black soy and garlic definitely flowing on your tongue for every sip that you take. Second would be the texture of the ramen - bouncy, hard (to my preference), and thin noodles soaking the broth nicely, and definitely leave you feeling satisfied. The char siew is worth dying for. Thin sliced, with perfect ratio of fats vs lean meat - sprinkled with little fried garlic on top of it, oh man. And surprisingly, itâ€™s not feeling over-cooked or over-grilled, like most of the ramen shop would go for. The soft boiled egg - definitely my kryptonite to see a nice bounce egg, with runny egg yolk. Hands down to one of the most perfectly cooked soft boiled egg. All the above-mentioned stuff, combined within a single bowl of awesomeness.â €
â €
Again, would say that this is highly recommended for those that love thick flavor ramen.â €
â €

I had the Garlic Ramen. It was amazing! The broth was fantastic. It was mildly thick and very rich. The saltiness was spot-on. It wasn't too oily. The noodles were good. The chashu was outstanding. It was well cooked, well seasoned, it melted in your mouth. Totally recommended. I am already eager to come and try the other flavors. The place is also very nice. Looks clean, it smells good. Looks well organized. Clean restroom. A cozy place. The service was fast and friendly. Not too pricey. The quality you get is worth what you pay.

author: NurembergAfterMidnight
text:
This place was hard! to find. It's located in the caesar's hotel. Find the side of the building to enter a food court. Google sent me down the MRT instead :'D

They try to make you order with your phone and QR code but everything there is Chinese. It's usually busy, but be persistent and ask them, they can order manually for you too! The food itself was delicious, tasted a little bit like Italian and Japanes food had a baby. But it's not that cheap compared to other places I ate. Vegetarian options exist and there's more than one! Cheese was generally nice too.

ATT mall can get really crowded during lunch time. Luckily we found this place which was rather hidden and not crowded. Perfect for us. Their menu featured beef broth ramen and luckily they had chicken broth ramen which we have decided to try. Surprisingly, the taste was really good. (åŸå§‹è©•è«–)
Japanese style Tantan ramen (tantan men).

The noodles, egg, nikumiso, are all great.
There are a lot of noodles, I might ask for less next time.
The chashu is OK, but could be improved by searing it (or ideally, flame-grilling).
The soup is very good, perfect spice and saltiness levels. You can taste the sesame, and it is not overwhelming. It is a great balance. I think the soup was based on a chicken stock, but I'm not certain.

They sell a special black tea from the boss' home town. I enjoyed it and will order it again next time.

I really appreciate the English menu, it is rare for ramen restaurants to have one!

author: Taro
text:
Had the spicy ramen with an extra egg. Total price 220 NTD ( 190 for ramen + 30 for the egg ). Price is ok. The taste is not bad but not a top ranking ramen level for me. The noodles are nice and chewy. I don't know why they don't cut of the bottom of the "bak choi" vegetable. Not easy to eat like this.

Friendly and fast service.

author: Wayland
text:
Still a short queue at 1:15pm on a Sunday but worth the wait.

The menu has recommendations for men and women. I ordered pork char siu, duck and clams with citrus ramen version recommended for guys. Also got the duck char siu rice.

Ramen broth was good and salty. You're instructed to not leave the citrus fruits in too long or else the bitterness of the rind will taint the broth. The broth was a tad salty and I can't imagine what the non citrus versions would be without the acid to cut that saltiness. The duck was excellent and the pork was ok, clams were good but nothing special. Noodles are thin and good texture.

Rice dish did nothing for me. I think it would be a lot better with a raw egg yolk but they don't offer that.

Service is good. Ordering is done via aachine like many ramen places in Japan. NOTE - cash only as the machine doesn't accept any cards.
